Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. div.p: REDMOND O'H‚ÄîN was the ≈øon of a reputable Iri≈øh gentleman, who had a con≈øiderable e≈øtate, and lived at the ‚Ä¢ oot ‚Ä¢ f Sleygunnin mountains, in the county of Armagh, among a va≈øt number of relations, ≈øeveral whereof were of the ≈øame name. But poor Redmond, in this unhappy condition, once happened to be at the killing of a gentleman in a quarrel, and flying for ≈øafety, ≈øtaid abroad for a long time, ≈øtill refu≈øing to come to trial 'till he was outlawed, which put him to his ≈øhifts. But our hero having received ≈øome in≈øtructions in the art of war, and being naturally of an undaunted courage,
was ea≈øily led into the ≈øecret of invading other men's properties, both on the highway, and by breaking open of hou≈øes, till he had acquired as much money as might have put him in a way to live above the frowns of fortune, with good management, all his life.

He had made him≈øelf acquainted with all the bye pa≈ø≈øages in the country, and he knew all the lurking places on the mountains of Newry and Sle ‚Ä¢ gun in, ≈øo that whoever pretended to pur≈øue him, made but fruitle≈øs attempts, and commonly returned with lo≈øs and ≈øhame, like dogs that lo≈øt their ears, both before and after the rewards were offered by the government for apprehending him.

He was ≈øtrong and active, and as occa≈øion required, could perform his feats either on foot or on hor≈øeback: but though he was ≈øo notorious a plunderer, he was naturally of a very generous di≈øpo≈øition, frequently giving ≈øhare of what he got from the rich to relieve the poor in their nece≈ø≈øities. div.p:
JOHN MULHONI was born in Connaught; but our author (not being willing to expo≈øe his family, which on his mother's ≈øide was of ≈øome repute) has concealed both his parents and the place of his birth. Upon this Mulhoni and Carrick, carrying with them about ‚Ä¢ 0 l. went over to London, where they ≈øet up for gentlemen, and frequented the play-hou≈øes and drawing rooms, like pe ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ns of di≈øtinction, 'till at length Mulhoni got acquainted with a rich merchant's wi≈øe on the Strand, who out of ≈øtark love & kindne≈øs ≈øupplied him from time to time with money to ≈øupport him in his extravagancies for about a year, 'till ≈øhe died. Then Mulhoni and Carick picked up Daniel Carrol as a man fit and proper for making a third per≈øon, being of a daring ≈øpirit, and fit to undertake any enterprize; and with his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance they robbed Mathew Joncour, E≈øq on Epping forre≈øt, from whom they took twenty guineas, two diamond rings and his and his lady's watches.

"Sink or ≈øwim, I'll go on with the game 'till I get money enough to make a figure in my own country," which occa≈øioned Carrick to alter his intentions, and make a new league with his comrades; ≈øo ≈øwearing upon the holy evangeli≈øts to be ever true to one another, they proceeded, and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the highway once more. But to be more private than before they took a lodging at Wapping, where they had not continued ≈øong before they pretended to have bu≈øine≈øs in Scotland, and were ≈øeveral times making a ≈øham agreement with Adrian Van Stoken to carry them thither in his ve≈ø≈øel: But while this was in agitation, they took notice that a Norway ma≈øter lodged a bag of 100 l. in their landlord's hands, who was a ≈ølop≈øeller, and having ob≈øerved where he laid it, they ≈øet their heads together to contrive how to bring it off

Whether the Doctor knew him or no ‚Ä¢ is a query, tho' he a≈øked him ≈øeveral que≈øtions as "What countryman he was, how long he had been in England; and where he was going?" and the like: but Carrick hearing him ≈øay he was going to the vice chancellor's began to ≈øu≈øpect that he was di≈øcovered, and made the be≈øt of his way (as ≈øoon as he got an opportunity) to his companions, to whom he related the ≈øtory; upon which they all agreed to remove their quarters with ≈øpeed to Conventry, where he held a con≈øultation to know, whether they had be≈øt go home to Ireland or return to London and pur≈øue their old cour≈øes. I ≈øay all the≈øe con≈øidered together di≈øcouraged
our heroes ≈øo much, that they no longer adventured to ≈øurvey the high roads on horeback, but bethought them≈øelves of a new method of making attempts, which was attacking pa≈ø≈øengers on foot by night in the public ≈øtreets; and more effectually to ≈øucceed in the≈øe new enterprizes, they made it their bu≈øine≈øs to pick acquaintance with the ≈øervants of per≈øons of quality that attended the Whitehall, St. James's, the Smyrna, offender and other chocolate hou≈øes, in order to learn of them where their ma≈øters generally ≈øpent the evening and to what place they retired afterwards; and having received information they commonly took care to way-lay them, and made the be≈øt hand they could of their captures. By and ≈øuch like ≈øtratagems, they ≈øeldom pa≈ø≈øed a week whenever they were in want, without making ≈øure of ≈øome con≈øiderable Prize.

It was cu≈øtomary with them when they met a chair conveniently with any one in it, for two of them to ≈øtop the men that carried it, while the third robbed the gentleman; but when they made an attack on a coach with but one ≈øervant behind, one was ordered to each ≈øide, and to have an eye on the footman, whi≈øe the third ≈øtopped the driver till the ≈øeat was performed. The ≈øixth adventure was at Marybone in Augu≈øt, 1721, where ob≈øerving that a baronet with one ≈øervant attending him had received a large pur≈øe of gold, they dogged him on his way home to a field, near the bordered hou≈øe, and took above 200 guineas from him, with ≈øome ≈øilver, a diamond ring and a watch, then giving the ≈øilver to his man, they padded the hoof and made their ecape: However the gentleman adverti≈øed the robbery, offering a larger reward for the watch (in the news papers.) than it could be ≈øold for; upon which they ≈øent it privately to the place appointed for receiving it, and got the reward, without being a≈øked any que≈øtions.

The next robbery they committed was in December following (and as they fully propo≈øed ≈øhould be their la≈øt) when having moved their quarters nearer to Convent-Garden, in order to be le≈øs remote from the gambling tables, in and about the little Piazza, Bow-≈øtreet, Charles-≈øtreet, and
Bridges-≈øtreet, they took notice of a Frenchman of quality, who lodged at a hou≈øe on the paved ≈øtones in St. Martin's lane, that had ≈øtripped mo≈øt of the adventurers at hazard; upon this they followed him, about one in the morning, until he came to the corner of Bedfordbury, where ≈øtopping the chair, they made the men turn two or three yards down a bye alley, and then robbed him of 230 pieces of gold, his watch, ring, gold headed cane, and ≈øword, which hearing the noi≈øe of mens feet behind, they took to their way through Ro≈øe≈øtreet, to Mulhoni's lodging in Hart-≈øtreet.

Though they were now put into a condition of living creditable, ‚Ä¢ et we may ob≈øerve, that by playing cards, dice, &c. and keeping company with lewd women, they were reduced, in a little time, to their primitive condition, poverty: and ≈øitting one day accidentally at the Ro≈øe-tavern, in Bridges-≈øtreet, they began to con≈øult how they ≈øhould retrieve their fortunes once more. div.head: The Hi≈øtory of Charles Demp≈øey, alias Cahier na Cappul, the renowned hor≈øe-≈øtealer.
div.p:
THE father of this Cahier was a man of as great note among the rapparees, in the reign of King James, as any that ever e≈øcaped the gallows; tho' after the kingdom was re≈øtored to its former privileges by king William's forces, he left off that practice pretty much, and lived like the re≈øt of his countrymen. He had ≈øeveral ≈øons there whereof afterwards became very notorious, viz. Daniel, Charles and Luke. Daniel was put to
≈øchool in his youth, 'till he obtained the reputation of a good ≈øcholar; but not being fond of going abroad to fini≈øh his ≈øtudies, cho≈øe to ≈øtay at home and lead the life of his brother, rather than be put into orders, (for he was intended for a prie≈øt.) When he arrived to mans's e≈øtate, he was too ea≈øily drawn into be a clerk and regi≈øter to his his brother Cahier, who could neither read nor write; and at length, by following his pattern, was brought to the gallows, and executed along with him in Augu≈øt 1735. Their brother Luke would have had the ≈øame fate, only that he fled the country, tho' he never arrived to half the dexterity of Charles in the art of hor≈øe hiding. They all under≈øtood the canting language pretty well, yet made no u≈øe of it but upon proper occa≈øions which made ≈øeveral of their neighbours think there was more laid to their charge than they de≈øerved, 'till time made the truth manife≈øt. But as our de≈øign here is only to give the hi≈øtory of Charles Demp≈øey, let us omit circumlocutions and proceed.

This Charles Demp≈øey, alias Cahier na Cappul was born on the lands of Glenmalier, near Ballibrittas, in the Queen's County, and in his childhood was kept mo≈øtly at his fo≈øter-father's, where he learned to ≈øpeak Iri≈øh, but little or no Engli≈øh. From his infancy, it was ob≈øerved that he was much addicted to lying and defrauding his companiona, little children, out of their playthings, and was ≈øo extraordinary fond of hor≈øes and riding, that before he arrived to the age of five years, be could ride and ≈øtick on a wild hor≈øe
better thau a great many men; a thing ≈øeldom known. 'Tis an old proverb, and commonly taken for granted, "that he that is born to be banged will never be drowned." Nor has it been more apparently verified in the life of any per≈øon than in his, for at the age afore≈øaid, being prompted by his natural inclinations to ride one three years old colt, he per≈øuaded a man, to put him on his back, tho' he had nothing but a collar on his head; but not being any way capable of managing the young bea≈øt, he ran headlong' with him into the Barrow, and ≈øwam it, tho' there was a very high flood, and the ≈øtream rapid: He held his grip by the mane very well till he got to the further ≈øide, but ≈øtriving to land at a bad place, the bank broke under the bea≈øt's brea≈øt, and ≈øunk with it under water for a moment, and poor Charles was wa≈øhed off with the current, which carried them both down the river near 50 yards, till the colt found footing, and plunged out; yet he held a fa≈øt grip of the collar till he got on dry ground, tho' he was ≈øhortly after taken up for dead, and with ≈øome difficulty recovered. After this he u≈øed frequently to ≈øay, in Iri≈øh, he would not fear drowning if he were to ≈øail in a turf ki≈øh, neither was he afterwards any thing afraid of the Barrow water, for he made ≈øeveral dangerous adventures acro≈øs to e≈øcape the hands of his pur≈øuers.

As he grew more cautious of pilfering publickly than when he was young (not that he thought it any ≈øin, but in dread of the law) he managed his affairs ≈øo cunningly as to lay the facts always on others, becau≈øe he had an inveterate hatred to
the gallows and the court-hou≈øe after Sir Toby's death.

From a child he had an ill-favoured a≈øpect, and in his countenance betrayed a deceitful heart, that is, he always carried a rogue's face, tho' his brother Daniel was a hand≈øome portly man, and of ≈øeemly behaviour. His Engli≈øh was but broken at be≈øt, and ≈øometimes he pretended to none at all, as will appear by the ≈øequel: And as the ≈øaying is, Save a thief from the gallows and he'll cut your throut, ≈øo it was with him; for his ingratitude was ≈øo great, and he had ≈øo tittle fidelity, that he made no ≈øcruple of accu≈øing his neare≈øt relations, or even his landlord, nay per≈øons no ways guilty or concerned, to ≈øave him≈øelf.

At the age of twelve years he began to practi≈øe the art of decoying and catching hor≈øes, in which he acquired ≈øo much ≈økill, that he made no difficulty of laying hands on the wilde≈øt colt, and hor≈øes that had been handled, ≈øeemed to fall into his clutches of their own accord. Perhaps ≈øome reader would expect that I ≈øhould give a particular account of his management in this affair, but as our intent in publi≈øhing this hi≈øtory, is only to put hone≈øt people on their guard again≈øt robbers and rogues, it can be no way nece≈ø≈øary, neither it expedient to teach a thief how to catch a hor≈øe, or to ≈øteal: If I can ≈øhew an hone≈øt man how to outwit a rogue, or put a trick on him, 'tis as much as can be expected; and verily that was my chief de≈øign in publi≈øhing this book.

But it fame be true, it will be entirely needle≈øs to mentionany particulars: the country people
will have and family do believe it was by a kind of witchara≈øt, or charm, that he decoyed and entrapped hor≈øes, and taught others to do ≈øo; and the affirm that he received this charm from a witch in the county of Monaghan, (with whom he was very intimate) for ≈øome ≈øingular ≈øervices he had done her. However, the following relation will make it ≈øeem probable that his father before him had the like charm; for which rea≈øon, I'm more than half inclined to di≈ø≈øent from the vulgar opinion, and conclude, that this magic was inherent in the family, and runs in the blood.
The ≈øtory was related by a gentleman thus:

"In the beginning of queen Ann's reign, I went to ≈øee a friend of mine near Abbeleix, and having arrived at the place, I walked about the fields in the evening alone, and when I came near to the bog, I found I had occa≈øion to ea≈øe nature; I cho≈øe a convenient place under a hedge for that purpo≈øe, but before I had fini≈øhed the di≈øcharge of my office, there appeared thro' the hedge a man before me, driving ≈øome hor≈øes very quietly into a corner, one whereof he took hold of him by the near foreleg, and held him fa≈øt 'till he threw a ≈øhert rope about his neck, then he vaulted on him with more agility than ever I ≈øaw a miller do on his ≈øacks: In this po≈øture with a long ≈øtick in his hand, he drove the colt (he was never handled before) acro≈øs the bog, till he got out of my ≈øight, plunging and leaping to ≈øuch a degree all the way, that one would have thought if the old boy were on his back he had but a dull chance from coming off without a broken neck; and by the noi≈øe they made, I conjectured they
might have gone a mile at the ≈øame rate before I left the place. I had no notion of rapparees being out at this time, and thought it might be ≈øome one that owned the colt that had made ≈øo free with him, till returning to my friends, I told the ≈øtory and then they all ≈øu≈øpected, as it really was, from the manner of catching the colt, that old Demp≈øy (tho he had been quiet a long time) had come to pay them a vi≈øit." Thus the gentleman ended his ≈øtory, and now to preceed to Charles.

His fo≈øter father was a tenant under Major P‚Äît, who once as he was riding out to take a review of his land, took notice of young Charles's activity in riding hor≈øes; upon which he had him ≈øent home, to him, in order to be an attendant on his groom, and to learn him to ≈øpeak Engli≈øh; where he behaved tolerable well and mode≈øt for a month or two and then he began his waggi≈øh tricks. "The groom and another ≈øervant happening to have ≈øome difference between them≈øelves, Charles was re≈øolved to wind it up to the highe≈øt, and bring a battle about if po≈ø≈øible: they had often been jarring and ≈øparing; and as the groom lay in a room under a hay loft, thro' which there was a private hole wide enough for a man to pa≈øs through, the young rogue took an opportunity, in the groom's ab≈øence, to drop a large ≈øur-reverence at the foot of his bed, not forgetting to be≈øprinkle it a little. When the groom was going to make his bed, what ≈øhould he lay his hand fir≈øt upon but the t‚Äî, which all bedaubed him, and threw him into ≈øuch a fit of anger, that he vo ‚Ä¢ ved to be revenged of his fellow ≈øervant in
the morning, whom he ≈øu≈øpected and nobody el≈øe. He went not to bed that night, but ≈øat up, and as ≈øoon as the ma≈øter came out the next day, made his complaint to him. His ma≈øter could hardly forbear ≈ømiling at the joke, tho' it was a dirty one; yet he ≈øhewed a very great re≈øentment to the other ≈øervant who was accu≈øed, tho' the fellow who was innocent, utterly denied that he knew any thing of the matter. All this gave the groom no ≈øatisfaction, but to loggerheads he would and did go with the other, who proving too hard for him, the groom was wor≈øted and obliged to give out; then the other, and all that took his part reported that the groom had S‚Äît his own bed and that he laid it on another with no other view than to excu≈øe him≈øelf; which getting wind, he was ≈øo jeered about it, that he had no quietne≈øs, till he quitted his ≈øervice and went away.

There were ≈øeveral young gentlewomen in the hou≈øe, who were very glad of the groom's departure, becau≈øe he was very ready in making complaints again≈øt them≈øelves to the old gentleman; from thence Charles took occa≈øion to let the young ladies into the ≈øecret, who approving of his management, employed him in ≈øeveral little affairs and about me≈ø≈øages not proper to mention here. But it happened once in the fruit rea≈øon, that the young gentlewomen had a great de≈øire for ≈øome choice fruit out of the orchard, into which they were refu≈øed admittance by the major; upon this they employed Charles to rob the orchard, who getting up very early by break of day, the next morning and without ≈øtaying to
put on his breeches, crept thro' a hole in the roof of the privy-hou≈øe, adjoining the orchard, and went to pillaging the trees, where he filled a large chequer apron, with the choice≈øt fruit, and was making ready to return. There was a clergyman that lodged in the hou≈øe, who had got a touch of the country di≈øea≈øe and was ≈øomewhat very much out of order, and having occa≈øion to give ≈øpeedy vent, had repared to the coffee hou≈øe for that purpo≈øe while the boy was on his expedition. As the gentleman ≈øat on his ≈øeat, and was ≈øtooping forward, the boy came to the hole, where, without looking before him as he was de≈øcending, the apron untied, and all the fruit came tumbling down about his ears; and at the ≈øame moment Charles fell with his legs on each ≈øide of the clergyman's ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k, and by the weight of the fall, threw him on his face, in this po≈øture they lay wedged together in a nook, for near the ≈øpace of a minute, before Charles could di≈øengage him≈øelf; and the clergyman's ≈øurpri≈øe being heightened more and more upon feeling nothing but naked ≈økin about him he fainted quite away; and lay-≈øtill on the ground; the boy thinking he had killed the gentleman, ran away with all ≈øpeed, and came back no more to his ≈øervice: But the clergyman who could not ≈øee him, and was as much terrified as the boy, (without ≈øu≈øpecting him in the lea≈øt) went in and told the ≈øtory: ≈øome pitied him, others could hardly forbear ≈ømiling; but nobody could find out the truth, but the boy being mi≈ø≈øing two or three days, and the young gentlewomen knowing the apron that was left behind, called to mind the exploit they ≈øent him about,
and ≈øo conjectured that it could be none el≈øe but young Demp≈øey, who had affrighted the poor clergyman into a ≈øit.

In days of his youth there was a miller, at the wind mill near Ballybritas, a fellow very fit for his purpo≈øe with whom he had picked an acquaintance. Charles had often been tampering with him to come into his mea≈øures; but the fellow had imbibed ≈øuch ≈øtrange notions of a Judge, that he thought he mu≈øt be ≈øomething more than mortal, to decide and give judgment on criminal cau≈øes; Nay, he imagined the Judge knew the truth of every complaint that was brought before him, before he heard it; for which rea≈øon, he was afraid of entering into any affair that might bring him before one, 'till he was fully informed what kind of a thing a Judge is. Charles to remove the≈øe ≈øcruples, prevailed on the fellow, who was very de≈øirous of knowing, to go along with him to Mary borough a≈ø≈øizes, where they heard ≈øome cau≈øes tried; which ≈øatisfied the miller's curio≈øity ≈øo far, that he told Cahier, as they were returning home, that a Judge was like one of them≈øelves, and nothing el≈øe but a man, and that he would be nothing afraid of entering in the li≈øts with Charles as ≈øoon as he plea≈øed; accordingly the fellow was enli≈øted and put into employment by his ma≈øter.

By this time Charles had picked up acquaintance in mo≈øt parts of the kingdom for putting his de≈øigns into execution. He fixed five or ≈øix of his own relations in Upper Ormond and O≈ø≈øory, and as many in the counties of Leitrim, monaghan, and Derry, be≈øides a va≈øt number of receivers
and a≈ø≈øi≈øtants in almo≈øt every hole and corner in the country; ≈øo that nothing went ami≈øs with him. He had likewi≈øe never le≈øs than four apprentices at a time, who were always bound for the term of ≈øeven years and paid a pretty round ≈øum of money for learning his art and my≈øtery, in which he had ≈øuch great ≈økill, that boys were ≈øent to him all the way from the county of Kerry, to be bound. Perhaps he was the fir≈øt Iri≈øh rogue that ever thought of ≈øuch a ≈øtratagem; for had he taken a thou≈øand pounds for teaching a boy to catch or disfigure a hor≈øe or cow only, I que≈øtion whether he could be hanged by our laws for it; and by the ≈øequel, we may ob≈øerve that he always acted in ≈øuch a manner as to be capable of evading the force of the law, if po≈ø≈øible, though he was as great a rogue as has been hanged.

He had be≈øides his Satyrs, receivers and apprentices, a number of ≈øpies and ≈øetters, who≈øe bu≈øine≈øs only was to make ob≈øervations, and give notice what cattle (and where they) might be mo≈øt ≈øafely conveyed away; and the≈øe had no communication with the Satyrs or drivers them≈øelves. Whenever ≈øuch notice was given to Charles, an expre≈øs was immediately di≈øpatched to ≈øome one or more of the Satyrs, with a de≈øcription of ≈øuch bea≈øt or bea≈øts, which, without any more words, was ≈øufficient to be under≈øtood. By ≈øuch means as this the downright thievery could never be proved on Charles, tho' every body knew that he was receiver general, and that his ≈øervants were all paid by the piece, ≈øo much a bea≈øt for officiating;
but how Daniel kept his accounts is a ≈øecret.

He had private places for hiding ≈øtolen cattle of all kinds in; and at any time when he thought proper, would order ≈øuch hor≈øes as came from Lein≈øter ≈øide or Mun≈øter, down to his corre≈øpondents in the North, who either would ≈øend them from Derry, Newry, on Donaghadee to Scotland, or otherwi≈øe ≈øwap them off in fairs or ≈øell them. Such hor≈øes, as his corre≈øpondents got in exchange, they made no ≈øcruple of ≈øelling publickly becau≈øe they could prove the getting of them; but tho≈øe that were ≈øtolen in the North were commonly ≈øent to different hands, and were di≈øpo≈øed of in Upper Ormond, O≈ø≈øory, or in Mun≈øter. To ≈øatisfy the reader's curio≈øity, I ≈øhall rehear≈øe one ≈øtory, being part of the confe≈ø≈øion of one of the confederates while he lay in confinement, before he was executed in Kilkenny, which will give a more particular account of his management than the foregoing.

He confe≈ø≈øed to the people who came to ≈øee him, that one of Charles's ≈øetters come to him by night where he lived, and told him there were three hor≈øes in a park near Clonegal; one was black, with a ≈øtar and one white foot, another a bay gelding, that padded, and the third, a white pad, with his mane and tail cut clo≈øe. He ≈øaid he under≈øtood the me≈ø≈øenger's meaning very well and accordingly conveyed the three hor≈øes down to Glenmalier in two nights after. After that he was pitched upon as the mo≈øt proper per≈øon for di≈øpo≈øing of them, and pur≈øuant to his orders took them down to the country of Monagham but as the white hor≈øe was ≈øo very remarkable
they ≈øtained him all over with a fle≈øh coloured red, in order to di≈øgui≈øe him, which was done with Brazilet and allum boiled in water; but that colour was ≈øoon wa≈øhed off. This fellow was not ≈øo much as known in that country; ≈øo by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øome of his Brother receivers, he put off the three hor≈øe in a fair, being all ≈øightly cattle to good advantage, for two of them he got twenty pounds, and for the third a mare, that was afterwards ≈øold in the county of Waterford for ≈øix pounds. Some after the owner of the bay-hor≈øe was directed to Charles, in expectation of getting ≈øome tidings of his brea≈øt: but Cahier would not undertake the inquiry, till he was paid two guineas in hand; upon which he promi≈øed to ≈øearch for the hor≈øe. In about twelve days after the hor≈øe was taken out of a ≈øtone park in the night, where the la≈øt purcha≈øer kept him and ≈øo conveyed down to Charles, who gave the right owner notice that they might find ≈øuch a hor≈øe in the wood near the river Barrow; upon which the owner ≈øent his ≈øervant for him, and had him brought home without any compliments. Some time after, the owner was riding to the North to buy linen, and having his hor≈øe with him, he was challenged and ≈øecured till the a≈ø≈øizes; but the owner bringing ≈øufficient evidence that he bred him, and that he had been mi≈ø≈øing all the while the other had him, got the better of the di≈øpute, and took his hor≈øe home again. On the other hand, the purcha≈øer could only prove, that he bought him in a fair, but could not tell from whom; ≈øo by that means the thief was ≈øeldom ≈øound.
By what has been related one may perceive how cunningly his affairs were carried on; and in the next place, I ≈øhall relate ≈øome of his own actions.

There was an elderly gentleman in the King's County who had a particular humour of his own in ≈øeveral re≈øpects, and when he took a fancy to any thing was commonly ≈øo choice of it, that he would ≈øuffer no one el≈øe to u≈øe it. He had a dun hor≈øe of great ≈øpirit, and a good hunter; which he was ≈øo choice of, that he would not ≈øuffer his ≈øon to ride him. The ≈øon knew the goodne≈øs of the hor≈øe as well as the father, and had ca≈øt a covetous eye upon him, but could not tell how to compa≈øs his de≈øire till he had advi≈øed with Cahier, who gave him proper directions. In con≈øideration of a hand≈øome fee, Charles, provided him with the ≈økin of a hor≈øe of the ≈øame colour, and with the like marks of his father's hor≈øe, which was then at gra≈øs. This ≈økin was dipt in a bog-hole and pre≈øented to the father by one of his tenants, as the ≈økin of his gelding, which, they ≈øaid, was drowned in a bog-hole.‚Äî The old man, who had not all the wit in the world, nor any mi≈øtru≈øt of the fraud believed his tenant's report, and took it for a matter of fact. However ≈øome time after the ≈øon, who had kept the hor≈øe concealed, rode on him home, pretended he had bought him in a fair; as ≈øoon as his father ≈øaw him he cried out, "D‚Äî, I vow to G‚Äîd, only my hor≈øe was drownded, I would take my oath that's he for he's as like as ever I ≈øaw any thing in my life," which expre≈ø≈øion pa≈ø≈øed to a ≈øterling joke among the gentlemen of the county
for a long time afterwards.

Cahier had occa≈øion once to pay his corre≈øpondents in the county of Kilkenny a vi≈øit and to examine how the affairs and accounts ≈øtood between them; where, as he was on his march in the evening, he went into a poor widow's hou≈øe, and demanded a drink of milk, upon which ≈øhe brought him a large drink of butter-milk but di≈øliking it very much, he abu≈øed her to all intents and purpo≈øes, and bid her go for ≈øome of the new milk, which ≈øhe refu≈øed, and would not own to have any other than what ≈øhe brought; then he called her a bitch and a whore, and cur≈øed her over and over, withal ≈øaying ≈øhe ≈øhould pay for that ill u≈øage: And indeed ≈øo ≈øhe did, for before next morning her two cows being all ≈øhe had, were ≈øtolen from her, neither could ≈øhe ger any tidings of them after.

Much about this time he was in his prime, and kept a place much like an office of intelligence, where his brother Daniel was regi≈øter, who kept an account not only of their corre≈øpondents and place of abode, but likewi≈øe how and for what every bea≈øt was di≈øpo≈øed of: By this means they were able to an≈øwer ≈øuch people as came in pur≈øuit of cattle: if they were to be had at all, he generally de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ anded a fee in hand, for putting the owner in the way of getting his bea≈øt, which fee was always proportioned according to the bea≈øt's value, or the difficulty that might attend the recovery of it; and if in happened that the bea≈øt could not be procured with any ≈øafety, he was to return ≈øuch a part of his fee as was agreed
to before hand, which he ≈øeldom refu≈øed. Now we mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that Cahier never delivered to the owner any bea≈øt that had been ≈øtolen; all he did, was to direct him to go where he might find ≈øuch a one; and this ≈øtratagem was to prevent home proof being given again≈øt him. Neverthele≈øs, he had the misfortune to be bit even in this re≈øpect, and catched in ≈øuch a trap, that it co≈øt him a ≈øummer's work to get lo≈øe. This was in the year 1729, when the practice was ≈øo common of killing ≈øheep in the night time, and taking away their ≈økins, carca≈øes, and fat, which they di≈øpo≈øed of in di≈øtant places. This practice was carried on mo≈øtly by di≈øcarded ≈øhepherds (tho' not without Cahier's knowledge) who kept dogs trained ≈øit for the purpo≈øe, with other materials.

A gentleman in the country of Kilkenny having ≈øome cows ≈øtolen from him, employed a tru≈øty ≈øervant to make enquiry from Cahier, who having received his fee, in a ≈øhort time gave proper directions, as he thought, where to find them. The gentleman managed ≈øo crattily, that he took up one of the men in who≈øe cu≈øtody the cattle were ≈øound, and this per≈øon having accu≈øed Cahier, Cahier was taken and put into Naas goal, where on purpo≈øe to ≈øave his own ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ k, he turned evidence for the king, and impeached ≈øix or ≈øeven people in that country. Cahier told the Judges that he could do the country a va≈øt deal of ≈øervice, that he could inform again≈øt rogues in every county in the province, and was willing to do it, to bring them to ju≈øtice. The judges were pr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ty well informed of his capacity of doing ≈øo; but not in ‚Ä¢ ggining
that he was a fore≈øworn rogue, they took him thro' the circuit to Philip≈øtown, Maryborough, Carlow, Kilkenny, Wexford, and Wicklow, expecting to benefit the country, by ridding it of rogues upon this evidence; but Charles took care not to inform again≈øt any one who was ≈øtaunch to his intere≈øt, impeaching none but ≈øuch as he thought might betray him, if taken up, or ≈øuch as he owed a grudge to, tho' they were innocent, and no way concerned with him. Charles has not been long out of confinement before he took a ≈ømall concern under a gentleman near Lea, on which he opened his office again; and as he had accu≈øed none of his ≈øtaunch comrades, they had no fault to his charge, but joined him very readily, and carried on their trade as before in conjunction.

However, one of his boys had given him occa≈øion to be angry on a certain time, for which he banged and abu≈øed him; the boy being ≈øtomached at this u≈øage, threatened to make ≈øome di≈øcovery to his ma≈øter's prejudice, which to prevent, Charles decoyed him into a wood (knowing that he could neither read not write) and with a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, bound him fa≈øt, and cut out his tongue; however through mi≈øtake, not ≈øo clo≈øe, out when he was cured, he made a ≈øhift to ≈øpeak, though very imperf ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tly.

At another time, one of his accomplices bro't to him by night, a very ≈øimple follow (in appearance) from upper Ormond, who came only to get intelligence of two hor≈øes that hadl been ≈øtolen from him, and had laid down a gui ‚Ä¢ ea for information money. Charles was then near the wind-mill, at a very bye-place; yet tho' the fellow was brought to him by night, and thro' the mo≈øt crooked paths, he beg ‚Ä¢ n to ≈øu≈øpect that the man had ≈øomething more in his head than lice, and was re≈øolved to put him into the high roads as privately as he came, le≈øt he ≈øhould come as a ≈øpy again≈øt him another time. After he had reprimanded his accomplices for intruding ≈øuch a fellow on him without previous notice, the two hor≈øes were ≈øent for, and ready to be delivered again≈øt day-break; then Cahier after he had plied the man with liquor all night, ≈øent for a large ≈øack, and having bound the fellow hand and foot, and gagged him to prevent him f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m making a noi≈øe, he was tumbled into it, and then the vacancy was well ≈øtuffed with hay (only a hole was made for him to breathe thro') to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ake it ≈øeem like a ≈øack of corn.

When matters were thus prep ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed, Charles mounted on one of the hor≈øes, and had the ≈øack thrown up before him, which he carried thro' as private paths as he could for about two miles, 'till he got into the high road, and it began to grow pretty light; then pitching upon a proper ≈øpot of ground where there was good gr ‚Ä¢ ≈øs, he took the ≈øack off the hor≈øe, the gag out of the f ‚Ä¢ llow's mouth, tethered both hor≈øes, and made off him≈øelf. The fellow had no other way left
to relieve him≈øelf, than by calling out to pa≈ø≈øengers, which he did very powerfully, but found no relief till about nine o'clock. When he was relea≈øed, he catched his hor≈øes, and made the be≈øt of his way home, for fear of meeting with a ≈øecond di≈øa≈øter.

Charles was ≈øhortly after indicted for ≈øeveral facts, and committed to Mary borough jail, with his comrade Jack; but the Landlord, who perhaps was afraid of lo≈øing ≈øome arrears, if he lo≈øt his tenant, made ≈øuch intere≈øt, and obtained ≈øo fair a character of him, that he was acquitted for that time, and his brother al≈øo, though it was very well known that they were pri ‚Ä¢ y to the ≈øtealing of almo≈øt every hor≈øe that had been ≈øtolen in that county.

But ≈øome little time after, the ≈øaid landlord to make ≈øure of his rent, ≈øeized on Cahier's effects, and turned him off his land. This put him to his wit's end to meditate revenge, which he thought he could bring about no better way than by accu≈øing him, and bringing him in as a party concerned along with him.

His former landlord had converted a large vault, that lay under an old ca≈øtle, into a ≈øtable, which was large enough to hold ≈øeveral hor≈øes; in this ≈øtable, and in a wood near to it (which ≈øome people ≈øay Charles did only through de≈øign) Cahier, when he had occa≈øion, had leave to put ≈øome of his hor≈øes, and this was foundation enough for him to ground an accu≈øation upon: Nay, he made preparations for giving in examinations, and the whole country believed that the
≈øaid gentleman was one of the managers in the confederacy.

Mr. G‚Äî, the ≈øaid gentleman, who was upon ≈øetting up for a ju≈øtice, being irritated again≈øt Charles, had examinations given again≈øt him, and after a very difficult pur≈øuit, Cahier was taken and committed to Naas goal, in November, 1734 ‚Ä¢ , where he remained till the March a≈ø≈øizes following, from whence he was tran≈ømitted to Mary borough, in order to be tried. While he was pur≈øued, he ≈øwam ≈øeveral times acro≈øs the Barrow, tho' the flood was great, and his ≈øaid landlord's men followed him with as much re≈øolution, till they took him, in a haggard, where he had concealed him≈øelf.

Things being now brought to this ≈øituation, he ≈øwore ≈øeveral examinations in Iri≈øh, while he was in confinement, again≈øt the gentleman and others, to put off his own trial, and told his ≈øtories ≈øo plau≈øible, that ≈øeveral gentleman in the country took his part, and the gentleman was tried; and were it not for ≈øome of the leading men in the country, it is to be feared he might have ≈øuffered. It was with ≈øome difficulty that his trial was put off till Augu≈øt affixes, tho' Cahier was the only evidence again≈øt him. But ≈øome others whom Charles accu≈øed, were tied up by the neck, particularly one Hickey, who owned that he had often tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed, but denied the facts whereof he was then accu≈øed, at the gallows.

We mu≈øt now pa≈øs on to Cahier's trial, at Maryborough, in Augu≈øt, 1735. He was fir≈øt brought to the bar, and then ordered to hold up
his hand, which he did pretty quietly, time after time, 'till above thirty indictments were read again≈øt him: Then the judge ≈øaid, 'guilty or not guilty?' but Cahier ≈øeemed not to under≈øtand one word of Engli≈øh, till one behind him bid him in Iri≈øh to an≈øwer: then he turned about, and a≈øked the other in the ≈øame language, what he ≈øhould ≈øay? Why ≈øays he, neel me dheer (i. e. not guilty.) The judge then told him, he would make him ≈øind good Engli≈øh ≈øhortly; and proceeded on, a≈øking him how he would be tried? but ≈øtill no Engli≈øh from Charles, who only a≈øked one that ≈øtood by in Iri≈øh, what the judge ≈øaid? But the judge was re≈øolved not to be tri≈øted with; ≈øo after much ado, he was taught to ≈øay, "By cod and my guntry.

At length the fir≈øt evidence was produced, and then a ≈øecond and a third, &c. but ≈øtill nothing but Iri≈øh from Demp≈øy, till a fellow from the North came up, who ≈øwore very home again≈øt him about a cow: Then all at once, he cried in a pa≈ø≈øion, "That's murder, my lord, he does not know m ‚Ä¢ at all; he's a lying rogue, for I had that cow wid my ≈øhelf ever; ≈øhe was born'd upon my own ground, my broder here knows it" Ah! (≈øays the judge) you and your broder.‚Äî

His trial la≈øted above twelve hours; for tho' there were ≈øo many evidences again≈øt him, and even the man that had lo≈øt his tongue, yet not above two, without other circum≈øtances, would have hanged him. He ≈øpoke broken Engli≈øh all along after, and pleaded very artfully, particula ‚Ä¢ ly again≈øt the ≈øaid gentleman, who was one of
the chief evidences again≈øt him. He always contradicted him, and ≈øtill would ≈øay to the judge, "That the evidence was the greate≈øt rogue of the two." But all did not ≈øave him; he received ≈øentence of death, and was executed in Augu≈øt, 1735.

As he pa≈ø≈øed from the gaol to the gallows, he minded nothing but di≈øcour≈øing with the people, who came to inquire of him about cattle that had been ≈øtolen from them. To ≈øome he gave ≈øatisfactory an≈øwers, and directed them where to ≈øeek; to others, he made none. On the ladder he continued the like di≈øcour≈øe, till he was turned off, and even then, he was ≈øo loth to die, that he caught hold of it as it turned, and held fa≈øt, till the ≈øheriff obliged him to quit his grip, by pounding his knuckles with the but end of his whip. Thus he went out of the world, without clearing any one that he had accu≈øed, and died according to the belief of every body, an hardened villain.

His brother Daniel, who was found guilty of the like facts, and executed along with him, behaved in a quite different manner; he continued reading, on his way to the place of execution, very devoutly, in a Manuel, and repeated a great number of prayers before the ladder was turned.
This ≈øame Charles, in imitation of Redmond O'Hanl ‚Ä¢ n, u≈øed to indemnify people from having their cattle ≈øtolen, for a yearly reward.
John, or Jack Demp≈øey, was al≈øo hanged ≈øome time before; but was not an own brother of Charles, tho' generally taken to be ≈øo.

div.head: THE GOLD FINDER: Or, the notorious CHEATS of Manus. Mac O'Neil, AND His Man ANDREW.
div.p: AMONG the many remarkable tricks related in the hi≈øtory of the Iri≈øh Rogues, there is none de≈øerves more the attention of the reader, than the following, being managed by an ignorant country fellow, who, by the natural ≈øimplicity of his look, and an artful affectation of folly, pa≈ø≈øed upon the world as a ≈øtupid, innocent bumpkin, incapable of forming the lea≈øt de≈øign or intrigte, which gave him the advantage of carrying on his cheat ‚Ä¢ ≈øucce≈øsfully for a long time, without being in the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpected. What province or country he was born in, I could never learn, tho' you may take it for granted, he was a downright Iri≈øhman; for he wore the brogue upon his tongue, as fa≈øhionable as any rogue in the nation.

At the age of ≈øixteen years, or thereabouts, he was bound apprentice to a Ma≈øon, at Clone-bullock,
in the King's county; but his ma≈øter dying before he had time to learn the trade, Manus was put under ≈øome difficulties; however, he made a ≈øhift to pick up acquaintance with an expert tinker, who had ≈økill in running down metal; and upon occa≈øion, was not backward in coining a piece of ≈øilver and gold, to an≈øwer his nece≈ø≈øities.

This ≈øame tinker had been tried for his life, for facts of this kind, both in Naas and Armagh, and found means to get off in both places. The Indictment upon which he was tried in Armagh, was for making and uttering a bad pi≈øtole; where ≈øeeming on his trial, to know nothing of the matter, he ≈øaid that not above three pi≈øtoles had pa≈ø≈øed thro' his hands in his life, and that he could know every one again; at the ≈øame time he begged leave to ≈øee the piece he was charged with for uttering, and if he had pa≈ø≈øed it, he would not deny it; upon this, it was given into his hand to be examined. While he was viewing the piece, he pretended to bite it, but took an opportunity of drawing another out of his mouth in≈øtead of it, which he ≈øaid was the ≈øame piece he had pa≈ø≈øed, and would prove it to be right good gold; accordingly it was tried, and found good, by which ≈øtratagem he got clear.

Manus having got a little in≈øight into the bu≈øine≈øs, grew ≈øick of Ma≈øonry and immediately fell upon new ≈øchemes. By ≈øome means or other, he procured as much gold as made a ≈ømall ingot, which he u≈øed as a decoy. With this he moved towards Allen, where meeting with a ≈øimple hone≈øt Engli≈øh countryman, ≈øit enough to ≈øerve his
turn, he took him into a private place, and gave him the following relation:‚Äî

"I was 'prentice, ≈øays he, wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a Ma≈øon, and at Ea≈øter when my Ma≈øter went abroad, he left me≈øelf and ‚Ä¢ noder 'prentice to maak a paar of pear, for a gaat at New-abbe), in the county of Kildere, ju≈øt hard by the old buildings: both of us had a mind to maak as good a work while my ma≈øter wou'd be from us, and better, nor af he'd ≈øten wid us him≈øelf; and I went wid my≈øhelf, and tin wid a crow in my hand, to get ≈øome good ≈øtones out of the old walls, that wou'd be fitting for us, tho' it was Ea≈øter Monday, and the people all at ma≈øs. I ≈øaw one plaas about ≈øo big as a door, ≈øtopped up wid the ≈øort of ≈øtones I wanted, and ≈øo I fell to work, ≈øtriving to get 'em out, and taak em along wid me to my comrade; but before I got de half of 'em out, I found there was ≈øteps up before me, going down like ≈øtairs, and I went in to ≈øee what ≈øort of a plaas there was there, and where ≈øhould the ≈øteps be after bringing my≈øelf to, but into a dark toom; I believe it is a want you call it, and what ≈øhould I find there, but a par≈øhil of ≈øhets, and I thought they were coffins full of bones: but when I ≈øtruck my crow again≈øt one of 'em, I found it's iron they were made of; and upon that I went out and ≈øtopped the whole up again, for fear any body would find it, and go in before night. When it was dark, my≈øhelf and my comrade along wid me, wint it there wid a candle and dark lantern; and what ≈øhould we find in the che≈øts whin we broke 'em open wid de crow, but bars like dis (pulling out his ingot) piled up a top of
one anoder, a yaad high, and fait I believe it gold, dar a neigh, look at it.‚ÄîThere was anoder che≈øt full of candle≈øticks of the ≈øaam ≈øort of dis, and more of them full of cro≈ø≈øes, chalices, and rings, and fine ≈øhining ≈øtones; my comrade has one of 'em, and a gentleman ≈øays it has a carbuncle. Do you know what ≈øort dat is? But what would you have of it? We took em all out of dat, and buried em in anoder plaas, till we got time to look 'em all over, for fear of the lord of the manor; if he hears of it, he'll come and take it from us. You mu≈øt not tell any body, only if you have any friend who would give us a little monies, he ≈øhould have a great bargain, for my ≈øhelf does not know the wort of ≈øuch ≈øort, and may be too af I'll take them to the gold≈ømith in Dublin, he'll ≈øhallenge us wid 'em, and fair may be we'd get nothing for 'em, but go to gaal after. Af you have any friend that's a ‚Ä¢ hone≈øt man, we would rather let him have a bargin for your ≈øake, than give it to a ≈øtranger; there's a crown among it too, which they ≈øay was belong to the King of Scotland.

The Farmer hearing the fellow talk ≈øo ≈øimply, verily imagined that he was a mere ignoramus, and thought all that he told him was as true as the hearth mouey; however he kept his council as far as proper, and de≈øired Manus to have his trea≈øure in readine≈øs, and not to ≈øhew it to any body, for fear of lo≈øing it, till he got an opportunity of acquainting ≈øome of his friends, who, he was ≈øure, had a good deal of money lying by, and would purcha≈øe the whole. Manus's ≈øole intention was to make him≈øelf ≈øeem as fooli≈øh as
po≈ø≈øible, thereby to make his bait the more taking, yet he did not confine him≈øelf to hold the ≈øecret from all others; for he told the afore≈øaid ≈øtory to as many as he thought he could make proper fools of, to further his de≈øigns, and behaved as much like a fool as po≈ø≈øible, that no ≈øu≈øpicion of deceit might hereby ari≈øe: for which rea≈øon I ≈øhall give him the title of the Iri≈øh fool, let others call him what they plea≈øe. By this arti≈øice, the ≈øtory was whi≈øpered about very privately from hand to hand, among ≈øuch people as were ≈øuppo≈øed to have money, who were mo≈øtly intent upon engro≈ø≈øing the trea≈øure every one to him≈øelf, that for ≈øear of being prevented they even would not give their wives an item of it.

At length, people that had money, came privately from all parts to ≈øeek Manus, in hopes of making their fortunes, but in fact it was only to lo≈øe them. The fir≈øt that he made a perfect ma≈øter of the ≈øecret, was an innkeeper of the county of Kilkenny, who had brought a pretty handful of money with him, and a portmanteau, in order to purcha≈øe a large quantity of gold; but Manus, as great a fool as he pretended to be, was re≈øolved not to be caught in any trap, and ab≈øolutely refu≈øed to ≈øell any of his ware under that denomination, for ≈øear of bringing him≈øelf into trouble, and gave ≈øuch rea≈øons for ≈øo doing, that the purcha≈øer ≈øeemed to have no mi≈øtru≈øt of a bite. Says he, "I don't ≈øell you my ingots of gold, that would be the way to be found out by the lord of the manor, who has the fir≈øt preten≈øion to every ≈øort of that kind that's found in
his ground any way; and to be ≈øure he'd have the gold above any thing el≈øe. I tell you what I'll do wid you, give me ≈øuch monies as will buy tin good cows to maintain my≈øhelf, and I'll give you ≈øo much of the ≈øort I found in the Old Abbey as ever you can carry way wid you in the leather bag behind you; but you mu≈øt give me your oat fir≈øt that you won't open it till you get home, nor tell any body how much gold you have, nor how you got it, and dis is ≈øome of the ≈øort I found (laying his ingot on a brick, and pointing to it with his finger.) Now, how much monies will you give me, and I'll ≈øill your bag?" The bargain was agreed to, and the purcha≈øer ≈øworn to ≈øecrecy; then Manus led him in the night to a convenient field for his purpo≈øe, pretending a great deal of fear, le≈øt any one ≈øhould ≈øee or hear them; and having blindfolded him, he took the portmanteau a little further, where he filled it with bricks, ≈øtones, and hay, and when he had locked it, he returned with the load. The inkeeper was overjoyed at his bargain, and having paid Manus about forty pound, earne≈øt money, he put the load up behind him, and rode home po≈øt ha≈øte, promi≈øing to pay the remainder on delivery of the key, which the goldfinder was to give him in two days after at his own hou≈øe, where he was to meet him and take an account of his ware. But the inkeeper waited two days, three times told before Manus appeared with the key, and might have waited till doom's day only his impatience prompted him to be fingering the gold; upon which he tipped open the portmanteau, and finding how
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nfoundedly he was outwitted, he ≈øell ≈øick of a Plenetick fever, which had like to have co≈øt him his life. However he was ≈øo much a≈øhamed of his bargain, that he could not tell how to divulge the ≈øecret for ≈øome months after.

The rumour of finding ≈øuch immen≈øe trea≈øure was ≈øpread about with ≈øuch artifice, that hundreds were apprized of it yet every man that had money and heard it imagined him≈øelf fir≈øt in the baby-hou≈øe, and ≈øtrove eagerly to make his market, before others knew any thing of the affair. I heard of a very re≈øpon≈øible merchant's son in the county of ‚Äî, that had ju≈øt received a con≈øiderable fortune with his wife, who upon having notice thereof, made preparations for di≈øpo≈øing of all his effects, in order to purcha≈øe the whole trea≈øure, (crown, jewels and all) and to carry them to France, about the time the late French King was married, expecting to make a million of money by the bargain, and to be able at his return to purcha≈øe the whole country before him; but the gay man his father being a man of better experience in the world, ≈øu≈øpected ≈øome deceit, and (though with difficulty) di≈ø≈øuaded his ≈øon from engaging in ≈øo hazardous a project.

Manus had ≈øuch good fortune by his ≈øchemes, that in a little time he was able to make a new ingot of real gold, which weighed about twelve ounces, in the ≈øhape of a ≈ømall bar, and this he carried about for a decoy: Be≈øides he was ≈øupplied by one of his accomplices from Dublin-with bra≈øs bars of the ≈øame ≈øize and form, gilded or covered over ≈øo that any per≈øon not well ≈økilled
in metals might ea≈øily be deceived, and not know one from the other. He had likewi≈øe the luck to pick up an acquaintance with one Andrew Farrel, an ill inclined young fellow, who≈øe u≈øual employment was to carry meat from the butchers in Dublin to gentlemen in the country. He pre≈øently found that this fellow would be very fit for his purpo≈øe, ina≈ømuch as that he was intimate with ≈øeveral people of good credit in Dublin, and ≈øo he let them into the ≈øecret. This Farrell told his ≈øtory concerning the trea≈øure with ≈øuch a ≈øeeming probality, that numbers entertained him, and treated him with a ‚Ä¢ undance of court≈øev, in order to get him to introduce them to Manus; however he always enjoined them to ≈øecrecy, ≈øtill pretending the greate≈øt friend≈øhip imaginable to tho≈øe he told it to, by which means he drew great numbers in ≈øearch of the gold. 'Tis really a wonder, that among ≈øo many as came from all parts in que≈øt of this trea≈øure, that ≈øome of them did not blab out one to another, what their bu≈øine≈øs was; but the my≈øtery lay here, tho≈øe that were in pur≈øuit, kept council of nece≈ø≈øity, and ≈øuch as were bit, were under the≈øe obligations, or ≈øo much a≈øhamed of their bargains, that they could not tell how to di≈øcover or expo≈øe their weakne≈øs.

Their mo≈øt u≈øual way of impo≈øing on cu≈øtomers, was this; after the buyers had been properly informed of the trea≈øure, and manner of finding it and ≈øo wrought up into a firm belief of the certainty thereof, without ≈øhewing any token of mi≈øtru≈øt; then Manus began to expo≈øe the gold bar which he call'd bra≈øs, as a ≈øample of his trea≈øure,
always prompting his chapmen to try it, let them call it what they plea≈øed. When they had fully ≈øatisfied them≈øelves concerning the value of the metal, a bargain was commonly concluded upon; in the mean while Manus always took care, by one means other, to exchange the gold bar for another of bra≈øs of which ≈øort be could furni≈øh his cu≈øtomers with as many as they thought proper; then as it was cu≈øtomary with him, he demanded either the money or ≈øufficient earne≈øt, which being laid down on the ≈øide of the table, and the ingits, as he called them on the other, "Now, ≈øays he, here is my ware, it is bra≈øs I call it, and will fold it to you for bra≈øs, and nothing el≈øe, but your≈øelf knows the ≈øort be≈øt. I hope you will have good luck wid it; a≈ø you don't like it, leave it ‚Ä¢ id my≈øelf; here is your monies, take your c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . I'll be bound to get more; but a≈ø you keep my ingits, you mu≈øt buy it for bra≈øs, and call it b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øs; and you ≈øhall give me your oat you will never ≈øay you bought gold, nor tell what you give for my ingits, for fear of the lord of the manor would come and ‚Ä¢ aak it all wid him≈øhelf." He frequently appeared to be in liquor, and by the≈øe kind of ≈øpeeches, which ≈øeemed to proceed from perfect ignorance, his cu≈øtomers only became ten times more earne≈øt than before, making no ≈øcruple to give an oath of ≈øecrecy, which being done, they ≈øeldom made any delay till they got home with the trea≈øure. But as particular in≈øtances may be more ≈øatisfactory, I ≈øhall relate two or three, to render him in more plain colours.

In the beginning of his pro≈øpetity, in company
with the ≈øaid Farrel, he took a jaunt down to Dublin, with the ingot of real gold in his pocket and ≈øeveral gits of bra≈øs, as like it as could po≈ø≈øibly be made. In the habit of a mean country farmer, he went to an eminent banker in Ca≈øtle-≈øtreet, and finding him alone, he drew out his ingot, and began to make his condition and ca≈øe known in the mo≈øt moving and pathetic manner. Says he. "God ble≈øs your wor≈øhip. Sir, every body knows you have the be≈øt ≈økill in the ≈øort of dis of any man in Dublin, (≈øhewing his ingot in paper) becau≈øe you deal ≈øo much in monies: I believe it is the fort they make the guineas of.
